ratings.comment: One of the most caring professors I have met at UW-Madison. Levine is a smart person who gained his Ph.D. degree at Warton. He shared a lot of interesting news and analyzed them using stuff we learned in class. He truly cares about our success. TAKE HIS CLASS.

Overall, a good professor. Made class interesting by discussing current events (my favorite part) which were sometimes related to the content in class. Tests seemed pretty hard compared to the content covered in the online lectures. Walked through problems in class to help with the problem sets. Very available for help in-person and on Piazza.

Prof. Levine is a really smart guy and is very passionate about financial markets. He covers a lot of real-world financial events that don't necessarily have a lot to do with the class, but it's still finance related material and if you're taking this class, you should really know this stuff. Class was enjoyable, 2 tests, 2 group projects.

Levine is a PhD in econ, tenured, and has only worked in academia. He cant bring material down to an undergrad level and Qs on exams reflect this. Qualitative Qs are about formulas and he only shows hard problems. Lectures are dry and he wastes time by talking about irrelevant current events and continuing ppts from the start not where he left off

Professor Levine is fine. He's a decent lecturer, but often talks about real-world events that don't seem to apply to the material; he'll often talk about them at a level many students don't understand. It's nice he lets you choose your groups for problem sets/projects, but the two cases were due before the material was ever even covered.

Overall a good class & I would take this class with Professor Levine again. Problem set questions are taken from the recommended textbook (can check out in the library reserves & answer key can be found with a google search). Multiple choice questions on the exams were harder than expected. Lectures brought in real world news/issues which I liked.

Oliver is definitely a smart guy and you can really tell when he actually cares about the lecture material. Makes most lectures fairly interesting. I found it difficult to get much from the lecture notes without going to class so really try to make it a priority. Exams not too bad, basically the same as practice questions/previous problem sets.

Levine is a very very smart guy. His lectures are intriguing mostly because you realize how he's literally making you a smarter person as you listen. Even though I didn't do particularly well in the class- a ton of highly competitive IB kids that worked harder than I, I would definitely take another class with him Levine guy is the man

Good guy who sincerely cares about his students and wants them to do welll. He tried to make dry finance topics into an interesting lecture and succeeds. He prints out the slides for you. Overall, relatively low workload and the book is not needed. The final was a bit of a surprise, but the class is curved. Best prof I've had in the finance dept.

I am taking Corporate Finance with Prof. Levine this semester. The textbook is not needed for this course. He prints out the lecture notes for you. He explains the concepts well, and the material itself is not too difficult. The exams can be a little tricky, but overall it is quite manageable. Also,there's a couple of problems sets and case studies

It was his first time teaching so he started out really bad, just reading slides that the book publisher provided.  Got better as the semester went along, started doing examples on the board.  Exams were pretty easy except the second one was a little tough.  HW is tedious.
